description: Basic subject-verb agreement with plural noun

input: I has been working here since yesterday.
expected: I have been working here since yesterday.
actual: I have been working here since yesterday.

input: Yesterday, I go to the store.
expected: Yesterday, I went to the store.
actual: Yesterday, I went to the store.

input: I am study English for three years.
expected: I have been studying English for three years.
actual: I have been studying English for three years.

input: I went to store to buy apple.
expected: I went to the store to buy an apple.
actual: I went to the store to buy an apple.
description: Article usage with singular countable nouns

input: Despite of the rain, we continued playing.
expected: Despite the rain, we continued playing.
actual: Despite the rain, we continued playing.

input: He don't know nothing about it.
expected: He doesn't know anything about it.
actual: He doesn't know anything about it.

input: He made a decision to go.
The man which I saw yesterday is my teacher.
expected: The man whom I saw yesterday is my teacher.
actual: The man whom I saw yesterday is my teacher.

input: If I would have known, I would have came earlier.
expected: If I had known, I would have come earlier.
actual: If I had known, I would have come earlier.

input: i love pizza but i hate pasta
expected: I love pizza, but I hate pasta.
actual: I love pizza, but I hate pasta.

input: Being that it was late we left.
expected: Since it was late, we left.
actual: Since it was late, we left.

input: At this point in time we should proceed.
